It's assembly-line art, colorful and professionally crafted... more imagination will probably go into the marketing of the movie than went into the making of it.
The story of this film is a bit forced, trying to shoehorn the characters and plot into a similar theme.
...boasts few attributes designed to appeal to viewers over a certain age...

There is no reason for this sequel to the already-pointless 1996 live action remake of the classic Disney cartoon to exist, and the filmmakers fail to come up with any convincing pretense of justification.
Sequel better than first live-action Dalmatians movie.
Beery, a former vaudeville comedian and cross-dresser, is an expert at physical comedy: his drunk act isn't very realistic, but it's fun to watch.
The film is so dated that it creaks.

King Vidor's first (and still best) version of this sentimental saga is worth seeing for the performances of Wallace Beery (who won the Oscar) as down-on-his-luck prizefigher as terrific child actor Jackie Cooper as his son.
This picture is a further example of clever acting saving the day, for there is little in this narrative of horse racing and pugilistic bouts that possesses much akin to originality.
A good picture, almost entirely by virtue of an inspired performance by a boy, Jackie Cooper.
A film with a lot of heart, unafraid to bare its emotions.
It was, from beginning to end, a moving picture, and not a photographed play, with obvious miniatures, backdrops, and stage sets.
No false attitudes, excessive expressions, nor a movement or a nuance that is not nature itself. [Full Review in Spanish]
What could've come across as schmaltz hums with the belief that what we're seeing is somehow sacred and true.
...a fine premise that's employed to watchable yet entirely unspectacular effect by King Vidor...
The Jungle Book is fun, cheerful animation; high on hummable songs and comedy; and low on scary moments.
..an uneven episode in the Disney legacy, without much shape and substance beyond the concept of jumping from one scene to the next in order to get to the next musical number.
The background animation is embarrassing, but the songs are fun.
The Jungle Book isn't without its rough spots, but on the whole it's fully deserving of its place in the Disney canon.
I'll never get that "Bear Necessities" song out of my head, ever. I guess that's a testament to the movie.
Pretty good, but not great later Disney effort.
Fun characters, irresistible songs -- a Disney classic.
It's also got great knockabout visual gags, mercifully little cutey-poo sentiment, and reasonable songs.

Whatever it lacks in heroic reach it more than makes up for in sociable personality and devastatingly expressive animation from the Disney masters, making it an underground classic that's impressively stood the test of time.
...the characters, music, and animation more than make up for any shortcomings, and the result is pleasant entertainment for everyone.
The roughness around the edges of The Jungle Book are part of what makes it such a classic.
The literally last-minute stab at domestic foreplay is simply unbelievable, but Baloo's lip-licking post-mortem ("I still think he'd a made one swell bear") is what sticks.
Reflects a conservative, imperialist, 'don't mix the races/species' worldview. Yet it's also about friendship and truthfulness, and it's just plain fun.
With an ensemble cast of memorable characters, catchy tunes and lots of zaniness, it's hard not to love the Kipling adaptation.
A witty animated feature from Disney based on the famous Rudyard Kipling stories.
It's a slight tale, of course, and incredibly short, but the characters and songs are pretty much perfect viewing time and again.
Ridiculously entertaining.
A serious disappointment, recommended only for inveterate Disney fans and very young people.
The standout song goes to Harris, a rhythmic 'Bare Necessities' extolling the value of a simple life and credited to Terry Gilkyson.
By far the most contemporary in expression and attitude of any Disney animated feature to that time.
Jaunty animation meets jazzy songs in Disney classic.
...a sporadically entertaining yet hopelessly uneven bit of animated filmmaking.
Every one of the bunch is memorable, and each plays gracefully into the action of the film.

[Blu-ray Review] Looking and sounding like a million bucks (or more) and full of exhaustive bonus content new and vintage, the Blu-ray release of "The Jungle Book" is a must-own for anyone who loves animation, the Walt Disney studio, or film in general.
Disney's grandniece recently cast aspersions on the picture, but I don't share her pessimism.
Here's yet another animated feature from Disney's mostly barren stretch between its two golden ages, a film that plays better in nostalgia-tinged memories than in the here-and-now.

The plot and pacing may be nearly as lazy as the sloth bear Baloo (Phil Harris), but animators use that to their advantage, developing the characters so that even minor ones seem majorly entertaining.
The result is thoroughly delightful. The reasons for its success lie in Disney's own unfettered animal spirits, his ability to be childlike without being childish.
The period's feathery drawing style abounds, and an all-round warmth pervades.
Smple, uncluttered, straight-forward fun.
Written by the Sherman Brothers, the songs are catchy and make me smile every time I hear them.
May be one of their lesser classics, but there is a reason why it has endured for so long.
The characters are effectively conceptualized and flawlessly realized.
Walt Disney Studios continues to make films that old Walt would have been proud of.
The movie is magnificently photographed on location. The performances are authentic and understated, and Brandauer makes a convincing veteran prospector, part hard-bitten, part dreamer.
Though slow and overlong, the movie is at least scenic family fare.
Grand family-oriented adventure on an epic scale...
A scenic and enveloping nature film about a young man and his beloved pet.
One of the best family films ever made
Despite moments of bravura and shameless tugs at the heart-strings, the film simply meanders towards a resolution. What's Brandauer doing here?
There is so much wrong with White Fang that it's easier to point out the good.
A perennial family favourite is given the Disney treatment, complete with soaring orchestral score and a sheen of sentimentality that all but masks the more serious undertones of the original.
Boasts enough nature footage and a strong central performance by Ethan Hawke to win over small fry
The beauty in this film is in its directness. There are some obligatory scenes. But there are also some very original and touching ones. This is a movie that has its heart in the right place.
Syrupy sweet, but just this side of watchable.
The ultimate tearjerker. Proof positive that Mac still has what it takes for a comeback!
Dreadful coming of age movie about kids and death. Kudos for the effort, but it's just depressing.
Coming of age tale tackles death; for older kids.
When I watched My Girl as a kid, I spent 80% of the movie having Schwinn Bicycle and mood ring envy. Now, I'm also able to appreciate [the] dialogue...
My Girl is an exercise in mawkish sentiment, an exploitation picture for the whole family.
[Grodin's] acting is so detached and lifeless that it is close to an out of body experience.

If I were under the age of 14 and had not already seen all of those earlier animal movies, I might well have enjoyed Beethoven more. It's the kind of clever, innocuous family entertainment that's always in short supply.
A waggish tale of canine chicanery, an uproarious if impawsible symphony of drool, doggy fidelity and chewed shoes.

Unless you are taking a child, there is absolutely no reason you should put yourself through this almost perfectly mindless exercise in canine celebration (exception: if your favorite comic strip is Marmaduke, this may be the movie for you).
The first half of the film is amusing, but when it turns to a distasteful subplot that has an evil veterinarian/scientist stealing pets for nasty experiments, it goes sour.
Family gets dog. Dog is large. Insert laugh track here. Still, it's a whole lot better than the wretched (and endless) series of sequels.
You'll laugh, You'll cry, You'll Howl?
Beethoven is no classic, but it's a sunny, energetic children's film with a good notion of what young audiences like.
Anti-working mom bias gives a sour feeling to an otherwise innocuous dog movie.
Overbearing (actually overdogging) family comedy.
I love dogs, but still had trouble getting through this.

Elevated from the doldrums of Digby-esque sentimentality by a surprisingly bouncy script, the film is also redeemed by regular interludes of acerbic dialogue and a brace of fine supporting performances.

Kids will 'ooh' and 'aah' over the shaggy, doe-eyed doggy as it demolishes the family home, but grown-ups should stay on the sofa and enjoy the acerbic asides which distinguish this offering from the glut of cute mongrel movies.
Rallies at the end to prevent chaperoning adults from feeling their time was completely wasted.
A safely banal concoction in the tradition of the bland live-action Disney features cranked out during the Magic Kingdom's dispirited years after Walt's death.
A sloppy but lovable pooch of a movie.
A family comedy about a wacky & destructive St. Bernard that is totally without any merit whatsoever.
Every moment fits neatly together in an almost machined way. But the time lopes by and a few of the sequences prove oddly delightful.
Miracle on 34th Street this ain't.
All I want for Christmas is to never see All I Want for Christmas again.
When it comes to yuletide cheer, All I Want for Christmas ranks just under dead reindeer on the roof.
Generic at its core, the idea behind the movie is valiant enough but happy themes aren't enough to carry an otherwise boring film.
...is a break from trash like this. Just awful!
What makes the film so nauseating is not that it's badly acted or made, but that its motives are presented with such sledgehammer subtlety that even the youngest children would feel insulted by it.
Clearly meant to be adorable, the kids crack jokes like screenwriters rather than children, and the plot is just as contrived as the self-conscious dialogue.
A lackluster, routinely directed and underwritten romantic comedy.
This 1991 feature is not for diabetics or connoisseurs of real people, but everyone else should have a ball.

For the few lucky youngsters out there whose lives so far have not been touched by divorce, this movie may stir up illegitimate (or, at least, unnecessary worries). Such realism in an otherwise fantasy-based tale makes for an awkward combination.
All I Want for Christmas is witless, insipid and insidious.
Because the movie seems divided about its real subject, it lacks the kind of emotional momentum it needs for its final scenes.
"Forever Young," which turns on contrivances of plot rather than aspects of character, is as cheap emotionally as it is ideologically.
The result is a movie that is more enjoyable than it has any right to be. And Mel Gibson's legion of fans will not be disappointed.
Awful ending.
Probes the anguish of not being able to share the experiences of one's life with the person that we love.
Mr. Gibson is good enough to give the film substance, making "Forever Young" far easier to sit through than it has any right to be.
Decent romance mixed with 1950s-ish sci-fi.
Sappy but engaging.
A Sweet Fanasy that wears it's heart on it's sleeve
Looked at with a jaundiced eye, the scenario is slushy and full of holes; surrendered to in a spirit of careless romanticism, it works.

Remarkably, the director manages to toe the line of melodrama without ever slipping over into camp, balancing those elements with humor and suspense to carry "Forever Young," if not over the moon, at least up in the clouds.
Hollywood used to churn out this kind of fluff with practised ease and it's a pity director Steve Miner couldn't have found the same winning formula here.
A ripoff screenplay as shameless as this might survive if the casting were particularly good.
Relying on his star name, the film doesn't have to be great and isn't, although Gibson and Curtis try their hardest.
What's great about MATINEE is how it introduces fantastic elements to an ordinary setting and weaves them so invisibly into the story
A delightful comedy and one of the most charming movies in a long time.
An affectionate look back at old-school matinee moviegoing.
An unknown delight.
A fun film. I wish they'd bring back some of the lost magic to 'B' movies.
Captures the spirit and joy of growing up on cheesy old horror movies. One of the best pieces of nostalgia ever made.
A riot, and Joe Dante's most touchingly personal movie at the same time.
Sharp and sharply observed period comedy with heart.
Uproarious comedy that film buffs should love.
A wonderful message about the power of the horror director, and what treasures they can bestow on their audiences.
This celebration of art over war is the closest thing Gremlins director Joe Dante has to a lost masterpiece.
Something of a forgotten gem, 1993's Matinee sits between Gremlins and Toy Soldiers in director Joe Dante's oeuvre.
One of director Joe Dante's finest achievements.

Released in 1993, Matinee - a loving tribute to the z-grade, drive-in monster pics of the '50s and '60s, as viewed nostalgically through the eyes of children - isn't the sort of film you'd see come out of a major studio that often.
[Dante's] delirium is both hilariously absurd and terrifyingly convincing.
Matinee is such an earnest film lacking in cynicism about the gimmickry of old that its warmth is infectious.
A tremendously sympathetic film capable of transcending the mere character of entertainment to become the most emblematic celluloid example of Joe Dante's work. [Full Review in Spanish]
Executed without passion, with faulty pacing, and predicaments that are too dull even for a family-friendly movie.
The movie is earnest, heartfelt, and, for all its lavishness, rather plodding.
Risking clich, we recommend that you stop and smell The Secret Garden's roses.
The story is familiar, of course, and hinges on the performances of the children. All three are much more realistic than most child actors.
The Secret Garden has at least two things going for it: remarkable acting and mesmerizing cinematography (by Roger Deakins).
Holland just perfectly captures a mood so dismally ugly or so cloyingly sweet that I, for one, felt like gagging. I admit what she did, she did well.
It is a work of beauty, poetry and deep mystery, and watching it is like entering for a time into a closed world where one's destiny may be discovered.
What a pleasure -- and what a challenge for the filmmakers -- to come up with a movie that exists primarily on ambience, character interplay, English accents and subtle class differences.
The young actors are quite proficient and un-sappy too -- it's not their fault if they too often seem like chessmen being moved around on the director's board, composed into picturesque tableaux.
An earth-cherishing drama about the restorative powers of nature, friendship and nurturing.
The Secret Garden' is a delightful film about children, but is much more than a mere children's film/
Ms. Holland's film of The Secret Garden is elegantly expressive, a discreet and lovely rendering of the children's classic by Frances Hodgson Burnett.
Agnieszka Holland and cinematographer Roger Deakins orchestrate the film's blossoming of human and plant life with care, transcending Hollywood's typical family fare.
With well-judged performances played straight, and topical subtexts (Green consciousness, the dysfunctional family), this 'children's' film sets no age limit on its potential audience.
What's truly marvelous about this Victorian fable is the wonderful performances from the child actors.

It is, first and foremost, a visual delight, a Victorian picture book come to life, from its brief prologue in India through its darkly enchanted recreation of Misselthwaite Manor on the Yorkshire moors.

Executed to near perfection in all artistic departments, this superior adaptation of the perennial favorite novel will find its core public among girls , but should prove satisfying enough to a range of audiences.
Great book, great adaptation.
The result is an instant classic -- rich, dense, resonant, powerful.
While drawing superb performances from her young leads, Holland has masterfully contrasted the garden -- a place where melodic robins seem almost conversant -- with the dread of Misselthwaite.
The film retains the gothic atmosphere of the book and looks amazing, thanks to Roger Deakins's scintillating photography. Stealing the show is Maggie Smith as beastly housekeeper Mrs Medlock.
That`s a more upscale marketing concept than Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, but it still doesn't make the movie any good.

The movie's dark themes, unhurried pace and talkiness make it something of a gamble for many children. But older children -- especially those who have been asking specific questions about death -- may find some nourishment in this garden.
This enchanted tale vividly shows how love heals and nurtures barren souls, makes them flourish like abundant Edens.
Rather than a fresh breeze, it's the stale air of gilded calculation, the uncomfortable feeling that things are excessively "just so," that overhangs much that is genuinely appealing about this film.
Though it can get laborious, and produces the odd unintended chuckle, The Secret Garden is charming and sometimes chillingly authentic.

Any kids' movie that aims for something richer than the Saturday-matinee escapism of smiling whales and preschool ninjas -- that actually captures some of the mystery of childhood -- ought to be embraced. whatever its peculiarities.
It's as if the moviemakers were trying to cook up a New Age Yorkshire pudding, without meat drippings -- what's missing is Burnett's robust optimism and animistic energy.
What magic there is comes from the odd, ritual behaviour of the children in a nice demonstration of the life-enhancing miracle of nature.
This lavish treatment originated from Coppola's Zoetrope studio and follows their several successful films made for family audiences.
An intelligently conceived and finely crafted picture with a G rating, a tag normally shunned by ambitious filmmakers because of its association with kiddie cartoons and squeaky-clean dullness.
Screenwriter Caroline Thompson and director Agnieszka Holland have turned Frances Hodgson Burnett's rather gothic 1911 children's book into an evocative, beautifully realized picture.
The film is gorgeous to look at, from its period accouterments to its wanderings in explored space (the house is full of secret passageways) to its use of color.
The movie enchants, with a visual texture that clearly bears the mark of executive producer Francis Ford Coppola and confirms the arrival of Oscar-nominated Polish director Agnieszka Holland.
The film has charm, without wandering into the realm of magic.
Visually, The Secret Garden is enchanting. Working in English for the first time, with Francis Coppola as her executive producer, Agnieszka Holland conjures up a fairy-tale world of images...
All in all, AIrborne is not bad for what it is, but what it is is very little.

There are reasons to commend [Rob] Bowman and screenwriter Bill Apablasa, who have gone out of their way to keep Mitchell's character honest. He manages to resolve his conflicts without giving up his values. In other words, nothing happens.
Fad flick that has lots of skateboards ... and literally nothing else.

Slackly directed and thinly written, "Airborne" exists mainly for its scenes of the big race, in which two teams rocket down a series of winding hills, jumping over cars, scooting under trucks and bouncing down stairs.
A helluva lot of fun......babes, beats and bad-ass skate stunts!
Tries for a genuinely entertaining dramedy while pandering to the Extreme Sports crowds, everywhere.
The occasional action scenes are as appropriately tortuous as the tired teen-out-of-water plot is torturous. This is a kid-flick that's speed-skating on one leg.
Predictable teen-slush.

The movie turns out to be hyperslick, quite well made in the technical sense (beautifully photographed and designed) and somewhat shallow, another exploration of that perennial and passionate teen theme, fitting in.
The characters are clueless; the dialogue is cretin.
Kids might enjoy this teenage fish-out-of-the-surf comedy, but anyone approaching the high school age of the movie's characters will spot the obvious formula within 15 minutes of opening credits.
High production values and a moderately appealing cast do nothing to ameliorate the tedium.
Instead of telling a story, the filmmakers follow an outline (or, in this case, an in-line).
Oddly enough "Airborne" is tasty cotton candy for the screen.

This situation, set in the 1950s, could be the set-up for a sitcom, or a retread of an old Disney family yarn. It ends up being a lot more, partly because Kathy Bates brings a solid, no-nonsense clarity to what could have been a marshmallow role.
Needlessly corny...a manipulative melodrama that wastes the presence of a fine actress such as Bates...Furlong's brooding becomes rather tedious in Bill's drowsy dud
Offers a flinty portrait of a single mother of six, who is one-of-a-kind.
Though Kathy Bates and Furlong's acting is decent, there is no reason to see this inspirational saga on the big screen; in scope and goal, it's a suitable TV Movie of the Week.
De-press-ing drama of Kathy Bates and her starving family trying to survive.
The film is really a celebration of the resilience of the American family.

The bare story itself could be simplistic and silly: Cops chasing a couple of kids on a horse. But when relationships are involved, and social realities, and a certain level of magical realism, then the story grows and deepens until it really involves us.
A family film in the truest sense of the word. Clever, wise, and endearing whether you have kids or not.
Unassuming and mildly pleasant, but mostly unassuming.
There must have been oofle-dust around in sackfuls to persuade Barkin to lend her aura to a project that asks so little of her.

Although it may not offer sufficient action and bratty humor for a contemporary tyke, this warm and moving story of two young brothers and a magical white horse will satisfy the same sort of parent-child combinations as The Secret Garden.
The pathos is powerful too, and one wonders why cinema managers don't sell packets of handkerchiefs along-side all the chocolate and ice-creams.
Even with all the leggings and horses and medieval gear, Walt Disney's "The Three Musketeers" looks more like a beach-party movie than an adaptation of a beloved classic.

It must have been great fun to make it (what young actor doesn't want to dash around on horseback and engage in swashbuckling swordfights?), but it's not that much fun to watch. It's all sound and energy, without plan or meaning.
It has the main characters and a hint of the idea but it's all go-to-hell fun from there.
Very mildly entertaining. Not even worth watching a second time, but it worked as a Saturday matinee.
Audaciously limpid Disney swill that's so slick it almost convinces us Dumas had an MTV attention span.
A stupid, bumbling misfire, which wastes a solid cast.
A bubble-gum swashbuckling adventure, rapidly fading in the cultural rear-view mirror. Still, it goes down easy, and Tim Curry makes a good bad guy.
A fun adventure, but nothing new. Average retelling of the legend. Platt steals the show.
Rewatch the Lester film or even the Ritz Bros.

Conceived frankly as a product, complete with hit-to-be theme song over the closing credits, this adventure film cares less about storytelling than about keeping the Musketeers' feathered hats on straight whenever they go galloping.

Those who have never seen a previous "Musketeers" adaptation or a truly exciting Hollywood adventure in the grand style may be swept along, but the mechanical, paint-by-numbers feel of this outing is too evident to ignore.
[A] sound adaptation of the famous tale, hewing closely to the story and its buddy aspect.
What "The Three Musketeers" lacks in poeticism, it makes up for in entertainment value, at least.
All this nonsense would be news to Dumas, whose grave is surely spinning as his musketeers - sucked dry of high drama and low wit - go kicking and screaming into the wonderful world of Disney.
. Her crazy adventure teaches Alice about change, the multiple uses of words, curiosity, nonsense, and the great mysteries of life
Dismal: Stick with the Disney version instead
The Flop that tried

review_content: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs may not be the best example of a Disney classic, thanks mainly to its lightly-plotted story, but with great animation, memorable characters, and beautiful music, it still remains one of their most endearing films.

review_content: The animation is spectacular, the songs are catchy, the dwarfs are delightful, and the movie is revolutionary in that it was the first full-length animated feature. But let's face it: Snow White has to be the most passive heroine in film history.

review_content: I didn't much care, for two reasons: Thumbelina's woe-is-me act got old real fast, and I couldn't care less about her matrimonial prospects.
A little more Thumbelina spunkiness would have gone a long way toward making this a more compelling story for kids - and especially for grown-ups.
The film is for very young children and people in comas.
A huge disappointment from Don Bluth.
I just think it's a fun little fairy tale [but] it's not good as The Lion King by any stretch of the imagination.

Under the authorship of Barry Manilow, it is not that the 'Thumbelina's' songs are abhorrent, is that, being presented every ten minutes in an hour and a half movie, they end up exhausting the viewer to unbearable limits. [Full Review in Spanish]
Thumbelina herself remains a complete drip of a character, insipidly mewling her way through the film's thankfully concise running time.
Thompson, also making her directorial debut, is undaunted by would-be neigh-sayers.
Stalwart, evocative and in every respect passable ...
This Black Beauty, unlike earlier versions of the book, wisely follows Sewell's lead and concentrates instead on this generous, trusting horse and the consequences of its encounters with humanity.

Assuming a good picture is one that transcends its own material -- pulls in a variety of people with no special interest in the subject -- then "Black Beauty" is a lumbering candidate for the glue factory.
Four (or more) movie versions precede this latest cinematic incarnation of "Black Beauty," but none have managed to capture the spirit of the book as well.
It plays like a cross between New Age mysticism and anthropomorphism run amok.
A wonderful film that is true to the letter and the spirit of this classic children's story.
This level of equine empathy takes getting used to, but it's worth the trouble. Ms. Thompson's film may be precious, but it's also rapturously pretty and filled with surprising passion.
Directing her first feature, screenwriter Caroline Thompson adopts a level-headed tone, avoiding the twin traps of sentimentality and sermonising.

Although already filmed three times in the sound era, Black Beauty has never been put onscreen faithfully or well, a situation partially remedied by this affecting, rather grave rendition of the children's perennial.
A harrowing and Beauty-ful version of the book.
An undervalued Chaplin masterpiece.
Hilarious-ness-ness
most overlooked film . . . contains some of the Tramp's best comic moments
It's a beautiful film and perhaps more personal that anyone might have suspected at the time.
Receiving his first Best Actor Oscar nomination, Chaplin is brilliant in this slapstick comedy, set in a milieu that fits him like a glove.
Chaplin's most underrated, consistently hysterical, and imaginative picture.
Chaplin's slapstick comedy worked to great effect.
In some ways The Circus is Chaplin's Stardust Memories, his reflexive self-observation in which Woody Allen's line, 'We like your earlier, funny movies,' flashes subliminally among the frames.
Innovative and timelessly hilarious.
The Circus may be the film that most definitively silences critics who claim that Charlie Chaplin's movies aren't cinematic.
It's a brilliant combination of light and darkness, tenderness and violence and, yes, laughter and tears.
There's an edge to The Circus that suggests a man gazing deep into the void, laughing at the darkness and urging us to do the same.
sort of B-grade alternative to City Lights

It is the political subtext and discussion of capitalism vs. communism that is the saving grace of The Circus, since the surface material, comprised of frantic slapstick mixed with maudlin and melodrama, is very standard for Chaplin.
The Circus is a magnificent film -- a mental tonic and a good hour's physical exercise. No one should miss it.
...a meta-commentary on Chaplin's own comic genius.
[Charles Chaplin] does not seem satisfied with the hearty laughs that used to greet him, but seeks to embroider his farce with touches of pathos that make one uncomfortable with their incongruity.
Even if it doesn't quite match the immortal likes of Modern Times or City Lights, The Circus still registers as prime Chaplin.
A sad clown masterwork that masks its tears with a smile.
while it is hardly Chaplin's best film, The Circus is packed with enough memorable moments, a few of which rank among Chaplin's greatest comic achievements, to stand firmly on its own
...one of [Chaplin's] most unforgettable and melancholy films, one filled to the brim with unforgettable gags and set pieces.
Though not without striking qualities by itself, it serves best as a poignant stepping stone to the auteur's later, more famous projects.
Still impressive sets and stunts have kept this from getting stale.

Fairbanks is the most exuberantly athletic of Robin Hoods, for sheer physicality perhaps outdoing even Errol Flynn's definitive performance. Fairbanks's third swashbuckler in some ways the ideal Fairbanks vehicle.
One of the great silent adventure films...and one of Doug's best.
Douglas Fairbanks rocked!
The lavish sets show such Allan Dwan enthusiams as waterworks (the moat), secret passages, multi-story architecture (the castle), elevators (the curtain Fairbanks slides).
It's by far the best and most joyous Robin Hood movie ever made; beside Fairbanks, even Errol Flynn appears to be standing still.
An epic silent version of the Robin Hood legend.
Through skillful training and handling, the use of dozens of animals and, no doubt, prodigious editing, these creatures really do commune with the audience.
Everything epic that Legends of the Fall strains so hard to achieve, Rudyard Kipling's The Jungle Book accomplishes niftily.
The special effects are convincing, the performances are forthright, and the direction, by Stephen Sommers, recalls his energetic, lighthearted "The Adventures of Huck Finn" (1993).
Putting Kipling's name over the title is gross mis-representation. The pity is that such care was taken with the visual aspects of a film so betrayed by the scripting.
Beautifully photographed and tightly paced with a spate of solid performances, this latest Kipling-inspired motion picture is an enjoyable and exuberant film-going experience.
The narrative shifts from romance to adventure the way Cheetah used to hop from foot to foot, but Sommers nevertheless delivers a bully family picture.
The technical aspects of the film are impressive. The cinematography is lovely.

Sommers would have done better if he had spent more time on character development (including some of the animal characters) and less on turning Mowgli into Indiana Jones. In some ways, this is as cartoony as the '67 version.
A serviceable adaptation, but nowhere near as whimsical as the animated version.
Boasts a hero who has a mystical rapport with animals.
A chaste teen-age love story with an ecological sensibility and some terrific scenery.
Excellent live-action adaptation. Thrilling adventure with classic heroes and villains.
Scott Lee is an unexpectedly appealing hero, partly because he's never indulged, and his dialogue is kept to a minimum.
Kipling purists may not cotton to Disney's new live-action version of The Jungle Book, but it's hard to think of anyone else who won't be enchanted.
A full-throttled, technically superb adventure - with more bite than most Disney live-action fare - that offers some winning moments but, ultimately, isn't as involving as it needs to be.
Rent the animated film instead.
Jungle Book entertains in a way both contemporary and traditional.
The new attempt - a live-action adaptation - is unlikely to supplant the cartoon version in anyone's affections.
The acting troupe are great fun: Lee looks fit, Headey is sweet enough in a narrow role, Cleese fine-tunes his predictable Fawlty bit and Elwes stiff-upper lips to excess.

That's the biggest problem with this Jungle Book. Sommers is so busy spinning his camera, crowding the soundtrack with animal noises and piling on the cheesy visual effects that he can't stop for a reflective moment or a character-revealing touch.
This Jungle Book, however, is more remindful of Disney's classic wildlife adventure pics than it is of a cartoon, and it is most remindful of that other jungle classic, Tarzan.
Anyone familiar with Rudyard Kipling's stories will be forgiven for spending the first half of Rudyard Kipling's Jungle Book squirming with outrage and confusion.

In the end, Rudyard's Kipling's The Jungle Book gains very little from this newest incarnation. As live-action fare, it has nothing on the 1942 version of the story that starred the Indian actor Sabu as Kipling's wild child.

This live-action rumble-in-the-jungle version of the story of Mowgli, the boy brought up to adulthood by wolves, may lack the songs and magic of the classic Disney feature-length cartoon, but it is closer to Kipling's original tale.
Frequently beautiful and with much to recommend it.
Stunning production design, smart pacing, and a well-handled romantic angle make for a seamless, if undemanding, entertainment.

Beautifully mounted and shot, "Rudyard Kipling's 'Jungle Book' " still feels somewhat callow. Its title aside, it never really deals with the issues that the great Kipling raised continually in his distinguished body of work.
A visual feast, pitched equally between kids' and adult fare.
It isn't Kipling, but it is good old-fashioned Saturday-matinee fun.
Lee manages to convey both childlike trust and manliness, handsomely demonstrating that goodness and strength can share the same form.
Despite all the obvious derivations from other productions, the harder edge and the continual excitement contribute to a consistently high entertainment value.
...as if you need to be warned away from a movie starring Chevy Chase and Jon Thomas.
Chevy Chase can save most movies from the dog they might otherwise be
Pretty weak little family comedy...doesn't hurt but doesn't help.
Only the smoldering sexual tension between Chevy Chase and George Wendt keeps Man of the House from being a complete waste of time.
In the end, Born to Be Wild insults the intelligence of both children and adults, and, therefore, is worth nobody's precious time.
This is not just for the very young . . . it's for the undiscriminating very young.

It's a shame that the makers of "Born to Be Wild" went to such great lengths to create an absolutely convincing gorilla via technical wizardry only to waste their efforts on such a trite, predictable comedy-adventure.
Obnoxious monkeyshines.
The film's biggest mistake is in going after the heartstrings instead of the funnybone.
Most of the chances for humor are downplayed in favor of a heavy-handed, sentimental effort.
Screenwriters Paul Young and John Bunzel... can't decide whether they're making a slapstick comedy or an impassioned ecological statement or just a harmless baby-sitter...
There are moments in A Little Princess when you may just want to clap from pleasure.
A delightfully enchanting family fantasy, A Little Princess has all the earmarks of a classic.
Cuaron's version of magic realism consists of seeing incredibly fanciful sets and situations in precise detail.
Enchanting family fare.
A Little Princess is a delightful film. Bring your children, or just bring yourself.
[Best character was] Indian manservant who almost never spoke ... Powerful eyes.
Mexican director Alfonso Cuaron gives the film a nice feel for a New York girls' school of the time (though actually the novel was set in an English girls' school).

From the exquisite costumes to the remarkable set design to the superb performances, this fairy tale comes to life in a way that makes you despair at its ending. But though end it must, its spirit of imagination and its magic of abiding love lingers on.
A Little Princess exquisitely re-creates the ephemeral world of childhood, an enchanted kingdom where everything, even make-believe, seems possible.
It's not only suitable for consumption by those over age 10, it's actually enjoyable.
The 1939 Shirley Temple version of this book came closer to capturing Sara's vitality.
No es una película. Es un trozo de magia esparcido sobre el celuloide.
Enchanting drama based on a children's classic.
This is a magical film.
A truly captivating children's film that never got its due in the theaters.
A bright, beautiful and enchantingly childlike vision.
An exemplary version of Frances Hodgson Burnett's novel.
An astonishing work of studio artifice, A Little Princess is that rarest of creations, a children's film that plays equally well to kids and adults.
Wonderful movie of a lonely girl's triumph.

This new version of Frances Hodgson Burnett's children's classic boasts first-rate production values and a political sensitivity befitting the '90s, but it doesn't quite capture the magic of the 1939 Shirley Temple vehicle.
Cuaron finds the perfect style for this trusted formula; what could have been routine kids' stuff flourishes with his sure feeling for space, light and colour.
Soppy and girlish in the extreme, this should keep even the tiniest viewer rapt, while all too many adults may fall victim to an inexplicable bout of eye-watering long before the closing credits.
The film uses studio resources to create an entrancing world both in New York and in the heroine's fantasies about India.
One of the very best children's movies of the past quarter-century.
Purely innocent, whimsical, and imaginative.

The world of Babe isn't a seamless one, but it's surely inviting and rewarding.
The story should be enjoyable for anyone in a wide range of ages.
Though the filmmakers romanticize farm life, they don't sugarcoat the realities.
It's rare to see this kind of care expended on any movie; on a family picture, it's a small miracle.
A silk purse among children's entertainment.
This is a good family film.
So bloody loveable that even the worst cynic will be hard-pressed to condemn it.
A hilarious fantasy, about a plucky piglet that learns how to tend sheep, Babe is a barnyard charmer.
That little pig is so darn cute.
In the end, the most impressive moments in the film seem to be the technical ones, rather than the storyline.
It has been so long since I've genuinely cared about movie characters in a lighthearted story like this that I nearly wept with joy.
A charming and ingenious hit.
It's a clever, witty, touching piece of work that, coincidentally enough, is also a decidedly excellent date movie. Really.
Babe is a movie made with charm and wit, and unlike some family movies it does not condescend, not for a second.
Through a mixture of imaginative storytelling, impressive animatronics, and irresistible cuteness, Babe casts a spell over all viewers -- young, old, or somewhere in between.
The movie, directed by Chris Noonan, who wrote the screenplay with George Miller, takes a child's-eye view of a world that is photographed to look like a storybook come to life.
The underlying tricks are never allowed to upstage the story in all its humble sweetness.
If only people would be more like these animals, the world, though hardly saner, would certainly be a lot more fun.
All aspects of the movie are top-notch, especially the digital and animatronic effects used to bring the animals to life.
This is the ultimate family film, offering all ages a fun ride with something to say buried nicely in the depths of its accessible script.
As zany movies go, this one goes whole hog.
Unlike subsequent talking-animal pictures, Babe is a movie in which the human leads matter as much as the animals, or more so.
The heartwarming Babe does for pigs what Lassie did for dogs: It leaves you cheering for more.
A lovely, intelligent gem of G-rated entertainment that is also rib-tickling funny.
A little moral masterpiece with its honoring of the values of hospitality, empathy and service of others.
It's a great story -- tender without being sentimental, great for kids, engaging for adults, and with a four-legged protagonist who's as good and decent a hero as you could ask for in Hollywood.
One of those rare family films that refuses to talk -- or rather write -- down to the viewer.

Entertaining and moving.
Babe is a weird and wonderful charmer based on Dick King-Smith's popular children's story.
A sweet, surprisingly moving little fable.

This enchanting, cleverly made fable, brings freshness and charm to the premise of talking animals. A sleeper, the picture was nominated for 7 Oscars, including Best Picture, winning one for Visual Effects.
Its seemingly effortless synthesis of humor and pathos [is] almost as wonderful as is its ability to capture the sense of awe and fear that attends youth's initial exposure to the big wide world.
This reviewer for one, hasn't been able to face a pork chop in the months since, and is still laughing at the vibrant joyousness of this delicious comic fable.
It's enough to turn you vegetarian.
It has a surprising charm.
Australian director Chris Noonan and producer George Miller show what real talent and imagination can do, even without big-name humans as costars.
The characters (both animal and human) are solidly conceived, and the storytelling and visuals are expertly fashioned.
Babe provides a stunning revisionist take on barnyard politics, and may change the whole way we view pigs politically.

This Australian-made movie has a darker edge than most American kiddie films, but a perfectly contrived happy ending should soothe juvenile sensibilities. Adults, meanwhile, may find themselves enthralled.
A dazzling family entertainment with enormous charm that utilizes breathtaking technical innovation.

Heartwarming farm story touching and a bit scary.
Babe is not, strictly speaking, a kid's movie. It is a preposterously funny fable that strikes a chord with adults, too.
The hero of the children's movie Babe is probably the summer's most likable character -- a pig so appealing he may have your family swearing off hot dogs.

For children, the movie will play like a storybook come to life. Adults, at first, will marvel at the special effects and puppetry. But ultimately, they'll be won over by the nuances of a story that finds a fresh way to deliver a timeless message.
A film that is exceptional in its technical effects and its graceful ability to entertain.
The plot provides a worthy lesson for kids, but it plays out like George Orwell's Animal Farm as retold by Barney. Kinda weird.
It's a delight from start to finish that will captivate children and melt the heart of even the grumpiest adult.
[It's] a comedy of animal manners that is much funnier and much cannier than any recent movie about human relationships: a lovely, stubbornly idiosyncratic fable of aspiration and survival.
The movie is at times raucous, but its spirits couldn't be higher, and the tale teaches a good-natured lesson about why cooperation is better than coercion.

He's brave and bright, good-natured and ambitious, naive and vulnerable. All in all, he's probably the most winsome orphan to appear on the screen since Freddie Bartholomew impersonated David Copperfield 60 years ago.

Thanks to well-trained live animals, clever voice characterizations and a big dash of muppetry from Henson's Creature Shop, Babe and his barnyard friends not only walk the walk and trot the trot, they also talk the talk.

Here's the summer's sleeper for kids and their parents, a terrific picture that takes a lot of risks and makes them all pay off in a charming story about a pig who fancies himself a sheepdog -- or sheep-pig.

Much to my surprise, I found Babe charming in an eccentric, oddly tough-minded sort of way. And if it isn't quite good enough to change my mind about the entire critter-chat genre, it is certainly good enough to recommend.
Wise, captivating and thoroughly loony, this artful little farm fable is one of those rare films that works for all age levels.

Overstuffed with subplots, the film is somewhat episodic in nature, giving each of the characters a few scenes to develop some depth. But their eccentricities seem overly mannered and the big gag scenes are not played strictly for laughs.
Jodie Foster's second film isn't quite that bad, even if it does resort to some we're-all-human humor and a fart joke.
This movie is about fixing the little cracks in love, and it's a fine example of the restorer's art.
Perhaps the most realistic holiday movie I've ever seen, this oddly charming, poignant, and blackly funny film is a treasure not to be missed.

The movie, which is about the Thanksgiving family reunion from hell, is not exactly a comedy and yet not a drama, either. Like many family reunions, it has a little of both elements, and the strong sense that madness is being held just out of sight.
Aside from a few effective, low-key scenes, the movie doesn't involve the viewer.
With many of the conversations going on simultaneously, it's difficult -- sometimes even impossible -- to know who is saying what and to whom.

There so many likable moments in Home for the Holidays that nail situations so aptly that it's a shame that there are so many more moments that leave you scratching your head and wondering what to think.
The film doesn't quite work. The goofball parts just aren't as funny as they're meant to be. But it's enjoyable in stretches, particularly when the zaniness dies down.
It's likeable in that cosy, wet Sunday afternoon, family sort of way.

There is a good movie contained within Home For the Holidays which I suppose is why most of the critics love this show. For me, there are way too many failed sight gags and characters that got on my nerves with their antics and mannerisms.
This is a film that has a lot going for it, but loses points on trying too hard to have too easy a finish.
Holly Hunter is amazing. When watching her you get a sense of her character's whole life, not just the time she spends on the screen.

Foster keeps the party hopping, although more dark humor would have helped before she winds it down with sentiment and bromides.

As the wooden puppet who yearns to be human, Benigni ... is steadfastly insufferable, from his naughty, nave stage through a transformation to a state of virtue that is steeped in a self-congratulatory martyrdom and nobility.
Benigni's folly...In every sense of the word, the picture is just frightful; it will either terrify children or bore them to tears, and adults will be rightly appalled by it.
A movie so bad that it quickly enters the pantheon of wreckage that includes Battlefield Earth and Showgirls.

Best described as slipshod, annoying and quite simply, shockingly bad.

Visually sumptuous but intellectually stultifying.

Benigni's Pinocchio is extremely straight and mind-numbingly stilted, its episodic pacing keeping the film from developing any storytelling flow.
The idea of 49-year-old Roberto Benigni playing the wooden boy Pinocchio is scary enough. The reality of the new live-action Pinocchio he directed, cowrote and starred in borders on the grotesque.
The movie unfolds in a clumsy zone between fantasy and realism, and in the end it's neither here nor there.
No matter how much he runs around and acts like a doofus, accepting a 50-year-old in the role is creepy in a Michael Jackson sort of way.

The art direction is often exquisite, and the anthropomorphic animal characters are beautifully realized through clever makeup design, leaving one to hope that the eventual DVD release will offer subtitles and the original Italian-language soundtrack.

What can one say about a balding 50-year-old actor playing an innocent boy carved from a log?
What remains is a variant of the nincompoop Benigni persona, here a more annoying, though less angry version of the irresponsible Sandlerian manchild, undercut by the voice of the star of Road Trip.
I can't say this enough: This movie is about an adult male dressed in pink jammies.

review_content: Its ecological concerns, nuance and occasional lyricism place it squarely within the Ghibli oeuvre but not among its masterpieces.

review_content: Pom Poko isn't regarded as one of the tent poles of the Studio Ghibli canon, though it deserves to be.
movie_title: Pom Poko (Heisei tanuki gassen pompoko) (The Raccoon War)

review_content: Pom Poko is so delightfully weird, and jam-packed with oddities, that it's never dull, even if it is sometimes a little too disturbing for its own good.
