Alice is a really good time, as well as a great example of how 3-D can be effectively used as a tool to immerse us in imaginary worlds.
a new story out of Carroll's mythmaking that fails to inspire interest, perhaps except as a rote exercise in mainstream weirdness.
...the visuals are overwhelming, the direction to most of the cast seems to be to chew the scenery, and we're back to a movie being released in 3D for no discernible reason.

Gorgeously mounted but fundamentally humdrum, Tim Burton's movie achieves sumptuous beauty with ease but fails to connect on a full-bodied emotional level, making for a pleasant but somewhat empty ride.

Rather than a Wonderland full of terrifying adventures and deliciously absurd whimsy, Burton has created the Underland, a place of terrifyingly, yet lugubrious, bad filmmaking. He dispensed with the whimsy altogether.
A visually stimulating rendition that nevertheless comes off as lamentably timid.
Visually splendiferous but wrongheaded, the movie is far more Burton than Carroll--and not very good Burton at that--and far less than enchanting.
There is very little to praise in what amounts to Burton's most mercenary movie.
It highlights Burton's usual strengths, along with no small number of his weaknesses.
Whatever your personal feelings are about Tim Burton and his body of work, the man is a genius.
This is easily Burton's finest work, and while he takes some liberties with Lewis Carroll's classic, there are plenty of traditional "Alice" traits to satisfy everyone.
He [director Tim Burton] beat the odds and made this Alice a real wonder.
Every bit of havoc and nonesuch is put in service of the story of Alice's feminist awakening, and it's about as exciting as it sounds.
It's become a common argument against Burton, this lack of dramatic drive, but it's true in this instance.
The beguiling Wasikowska tethers the arcane anarchy with weight and emotional clarity, anchoring us as moviegoers to Alice's plight in both universes, up and under.
Its single biggest failing -- an affront to Lewis Carroll and the charms of nonsense literature -- is the fact that it makes sense.
It's very cool to look at, Depp is entertaining, Helena Bonham Carter is memorably crazy, and the too-conventional you-go-girl plotline is just an add-on to the visual cake.
Despite its flaws, Wonderland is stuffed with more minute to minute amusement than you're likely to get in anything else drifting through theaters, in or out of the third dimension.
A stream of consciousness collection of magical encounters and whimsical characters.

The true three-dimensionality here is the old-fashioned kind -- Wasikowska's fully rounded performance. Throughout the technical razzle-dazzle, we keep returning to the pallor of that face, the gravity in those eyes.
The picture is oddly flat -- a disjointed pageant of virtuoso effects. It's a triumph of design that falls short of wonderment.
Visually stunning and sporadically amusing, but lacks thrills, heart and cleverness. It's ultimately too scary for little kids and too unimaginative, pedestrian and bland for grown-ups.
Despite its sluggish start, "Alice" is an enchanting, witty and funny adventure filled with marvelous sights and set pieces.
A visually imaginative fairy tale that suffers slightly from its predictable course but still manages to wow at all the crucial moments.
All new 3-D Alice story is trippy and intense.
Burton and Disney have found a glorious way to interpret fairy tales and fantasies.
You leave the theater with a pleasant grin on your face, but by no means is it as wide as the Cheshire Cat's, and that's a shame.
No knockouts here. No tkos, either.
Purists will be perplexed and the average moviegoer ultimately disinterested by director Tim Burton's pedestrian spin of Lewis Carroll's 1865 classic.

It jumbles together a half-dozen or so other overproduced fantasies and wraps them up with typical, tiresome Disney bromides and just enough snippets from the originals to remind you of what you're missing.
Tim Burton's muddled take on the classic Lewis Carroll tale has moments of lucidity but mostly seems as confused as its titular heroine.
Burton brings his distinctive touch and Johnny Depp, Mia Wasikowska and Helena Bonham Carter do their stuff but a hodgepodge of Hollywood conventionality lessens the wonder.
There are certain cine-marriages that generate an indelible spark all their own. Tracy & Hepburn, Bogie & Bacall -- and now we get Tim Burton & 3D, creating the world we hoped for, and so much more.
The trippy tale may divide audiences -- Burton's version remains a children's story, though some may find it too over-the-top and idiosyncratic -- but to Us, it's a visual feast
a decent movie, but not the amazing, mindblowing, set the world on fire, change your life and curl your toes film people expect and want.
This Alice is a dud. If you want to experience a strange, unworldly story%u2014something like Tim Burton films used to provide%u2014stay home and read the book.
Much of Carroll's magical nonsense remains, even if Burton's film wobbles at the gates of anarchy and ends up being a more average affair than many might expect.
Such a delightfully giddy, silly, delirious movie. Tim Burton isn't being "Tim Burton" but is just having fun again, scrambling up the expected pieces
Disney family fun with the odd carefully calculated dark patch. Fine on its own terms, but a let-down given the talent involved. Disappointinger and disappointinger.
I can't rid myself of the feeling that for all the funkily crepuscular mood that Burton creates, this is a pretty conventional work.
Rated PG, according to the MPAA, for fantasy violence and 'a smoking caterpillar.' The Jefferson Airplane would be proud; Lewis Carroll devotees, however, may be less than enthusiastic...
Impressive eye-candy, elaborate and gorgeously detailed in wall-to-wall CGI (the 3-D seems rather half-hearted though; this is one that won't suffer much in regular old 2-D).

The episodic nature of Lewis Carroll's Alice in Wonderland doesn't really lend itself to traditional three-act plotting, but screenwriter Linda Woolverton puts Alice through her Joseph Campbell reluctant-hero paces, and none of it ever sparks.
If it could be bottled up, the label would read "watch me."
A sumptuous, bar-raising cinematic portmanteau that both honors and complements the source material.
The film is like eating an amazing peanut butter and jelly sandwich except that Tim Burton forgot to cut off the crust. The beginning and the end could have been cut out.
On paper, Tim Burton and Johnny Depp loose among the Wonderland weirdoes, in 3-D no less, sounded sensational. But it's a rather bland, forgettable flick.
Burton's turned Alice in Wonderland into a silver screen suicide note, once again mistaking an extended stay in hostility as a directorial statement of integrity.
The wavering tone is as uncertain as Alice's decision-making, while the added-on 3-D is a distraction and as unconvincing as the entire misconceived venture.
Tim Burton seems to have completely misinterpreted his source material, but that's hardly a surprise at this point. It's more like his trademark.
What's shocking about Alice in Wonderland is just how woefully conventional it all is.

Is Alice In Wonderland worth seeing? Yes, because it's a feast for the eyes. But the story needed to be more imaginative and involving for this to become a massive hit, and it's far from obvious whether it's aimed at children or adults.
Burton doesn't just hit the bottom of the barrel but drills through the wood and starts tunnelling. Its only saving grace are the arresting, if familiar, visuals.
It's nowhere near his best work but a superb voice cast, Helena Bonham Carter and a few moments of brilliance see it through.
A film adaptation should, of course, treat its source material as inspiration rather than dogma. But did Burton have to get the books so entirely wrong?
It is time for Tim Burton to get his nose out of his own sketchbook.

A succession of chases and fanciful combats, more akin to Dungeons & Dragons than to Carroll, leads to a peculiarly truncated climax. The 3-D effects are enjoyable, but the added depth can't make up for deficits in the concept or the plot.
You cannot believe the dreadfulness of Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland - gifted director takes on gaga script - until you see it. Enchantment has gone thataway.
IBurton and Woolverton pursue a message of self-fulfilment, not as vigorously as they might chase a rabbit but to the same delightful end.
You leave the theater with a pleasant grin on your face, but by no means is it as wide as the Cheshire Cat's, and that's a shame.
Depp and Burton's take on the Wonderland franchise is frivolous and feckless, a charming little pleasure to welcome the warmer weather.
I found myself trying so hard to like Alice in Wonderland that the process of watching it exhausted me.

Burton, once a master of CGI, has gradually become its servant, or at least has allowed the studio to. The madcap ringmaster of Gothic phantasmagoria does not exert his individual stamp on a book one might have thought he was born to film.

CGI has not been good to Tim Burton. The ability to see every unrestrained nuance of his vision fulfilled has robbed his films of the creative zest and inventive verve which marked his earlier classics.

Burton's Alice In Wonderland joins the ranks of Return To Oz and Hook in confirming that it's rarely a good idea to return to the scene of a classic novel unless you have something new and exciting to bring.

Who'd ever have thought you'd be able to complain that a Burton film wasn't disturbing enough? If it wasn't for Johnny Depp's blissfully demented Mad Hatter, this would have all the suggestive menace of a pink fairy cake.
The film, overall, seems familiar, and one didn't used to feel that about Burton, which probably means he needs to dig deeper next time in search of true oddity.
After the first 45 minutes, the film becomes as tedious as Johnny Depp's accent.
This magical world looks fantastic, especially in 3D.
The visuals are stunning, as you would expect, but characterisation is weak, and Depp's turn is one bout of lunacy too far.
A generic, joyless adventure story.
It's a workmanlike effort that will enchant all but the youngest children while holding the interest of parents. That, by definition, makes for a worthwhile family outing.
Alice in Wonderland is, strangely, about the movie you'd expect based on the talent involved.
You would think that a director like Burton would be at home in the Lewis Carroll universe, and maybe that is part of the problem.
The off-kiltered Tim Burton version of Alice in Wonderland might frightened younger children, confuse older ones and bore the adults.
These aren't actors working in front of blue screens with obvious effects dubbed in later. You really are in Wonderland. Real life and CGI are seamless.

Visually, which is where this 'Alice' really radiates, there are many riches. Ken Ralston's visual effects are stunning and surreal; Colleen Atwood's costumes are dazzling; and Dariusz Wolski's photography is spot on.
Hooray! Tim Burton's amazingly bizarre 'Alice in Wonderland' helped snap me out of my 2010 movie doldrums.
Lower your expectations, because Tim Burton has created a great canvas, just not a great film.
...a feast for the mind, if not necessarily the intellect
This Alice is more Ripley, or Lara Croft, than timeless story heroine.
If you're taking pulls from the Blue Caterpillar's hookah atop his magic mushroom, you care more about Hot Pockets than narrative integrity.

With its busy world teeming with sights but somehow as hollow at its core as say, a rabbit hole, the movie is a little like a splendid feast for the eyes, and not intended for devouring. Or rather, a tantalizing travelogue a little heavy on tunnel vision.
21st Century Alice matures and enters The Matrix!
The visual splendor is more than enough to feast your eyes on, so it's too bad that the dialogue in the film couldn't live up to its look.
Alice in Wonderland reminds me most of Sleepy Hollow: empty, faux-atmospheric, and without soul.

I appreciate Burton's love for the characters as he expresses it through such creative wizardry. But, then, I also have a wistful feeling over the lightness of its total affect. A delicious snack but not quite a full meal.
The movie feels wrong. I liked the individual pieces but it never works as a whole. It's too much like Burton's other work and the 3D was awful.
Alice in Wonderland is a lovely display of Tim Burton's amazing offbeat aesthetics which win me over every time, but sadly doesn't make for very much of a film.
If there was one adjective I could pick to describe this new adaptation, it would be "dispirited"
This creation is nice to look at but lacks energy, curiosity, or any kind of emotional draw.
This isn't so much a movie but the coffeetable book about the movie's production design...
I didn't find it to be the masterpiece I'd hoped for. It's good. It's very good -- and there are flashes of greatness within it.
Great visuals, but lacking in story.
Tim Burton's latest assault on the senses is partially redeemed by Johnny Depp's brilliant acting.
...enormously entertaining...Depp gives a performance that must be seen to be appreciated. He shows here that he is something special.

Pese al flojo argumento, visualmente el filme es una fiesta, rescatando el oscuro estilo Burtoniano pero asaltado ahora por la rebeldía del color en una dirección de arte realmente preciosista. En este contexto, la realización brillantemente hace justicia
(Burton)is the perfect person to put in charge of translating the magical world that Carroll created to the big screen.
Alice, a wonder to behold, but cold.
The Tim Burton-Johnny Depp combo comes in colors and whimsy, but lacks tension
Carroll's whimsical fantasy is transformed... into a bombastic action movie with traces of J.R.R. Tolkien.
There is mold all over this "Alice," and while some of it features the brightest of greens, a lot of it is predictably grim, but not in the way that Burton fans have come to savor.
First-rate fantasy....made even better with digital 3D technology. Tim Burton can be hit or miss. This one's a hit. Paul Chambers, CNN.
I'm not sure what I would have wanted instead of this. All I do know is that this version of Alice and Wonderland, for all its razzle and its dazzle, left me feeling decidedly unmoved.
The fact remains -- Alice doesn't live here anymore.
It's something like a post-modern tale of self-discovery, although it works better as a nutty fantasy than as anything with a point.
Quite tiresome in the end.
I found Tim Burton's Alice in Wonderland to be a treasure trove full of delight and near-amazement. The imagery is bold and ravishing. Alice in Wonderland is surreal and smashing.
Burton manages to put his unique visual spin on the familiar elements of the story, although he never quite reaches the heights of Jefferson Airplane's immortal anthem "White Rabbit"

Dulled down by a leaden epic formula, the plot becomes jerkily predictable on its Lord of the Rings route. Comedy and charming daffiness are sorely lacking--it's mostly ashen doom and gloom. 'Tediouser and tediouser!' cried Alice.
Not to say that Tim Burton's made a bad film, more that this is a missed opportunity.
Burton treats the eyes and tickles the funny bone, no doubt, but the heart and mind are left wanting.
The look of the film is electric with amazing creatures and incredibly varied landscapes from lush to bleak.
Alice In Wonderland may look fantastic, but there's little else going for it. It's emotionally cold, utterly predictable and there's never any sense of peril.
This may be the most fantastic, wondrous, and sinister realization of Alice's wonderland to date.
Tim Burton is the kind of director who probably does come up with six impossible things before breakfast. So it was a surprise to see him produce a film so lacking in joy, innovation and curiosity.
Re-emphasizes the nagging impression that the director is stuck in a creative rut, making pictures that are a tad too well-suited for his idiosyncratic style.

What should have been an eye-popping and jaw-dropping dream combination of two celebrated fabulists is instead a dour and unpleasant disaster that reduces one of the great modern mythical tales into a ugly mess
Alice in Wonderland lands in a comfortable zone that should accommodate both kids and adults.

La imaginación visual de Tim Burton encuentra terreno fértil en los personajes de Lewis Carroll, pero el resultado luce poco original y sorpresivo. Quien se destaca es Helena Bonham Carter como la irritable Reina Roja.
It's a weak structure, thinly tied to the picture's tired and antiquated theme about Alice reclaiming her "muchness" and defying societal expectations.
The Tim Burton-Johnny Depp combo comes in colors and whimsy, but lacks tension
Alice in Wonderland is normally not my cup of tea, but I was happy I joined the tea party this time.
Logic and proportion have seldom fallen so shruggingly dead
For better or for worse, it's Burton's imagination that keeps the proceedings lively, even if its' not as blatantly humorous as we'd like.
Vizualno atraktivan film prepun grotesknih likova i CGI-efekata o kojima se donedavno nije moglo sanjati
Burton's personal stamp is missing. On Alice he is a director for hire, helping the Disney empire repurpose one of its animated properties and reinforce its 3-D bulkhead.
...[Burton] made an Alice in Wonderland film that wasn't Alice in Wonderland. Kinda.
A head trip into blunderland.
Kids will enjoy the characters and the 3D. But grownups? Well, not this grownup, who is a Tim Burton/Johnny Depp fan, and who expected more.
Anne Hathaway is ridiculously miscast as a deliberately weird White Queen, although the character is supposed to represent Good against the Red Queen's evil.

Johnny Depp, basicamente dependendo apenas da maquiagem e de próteses, investe numa composição caricata como o personagem exige ao mesmo tempo em que se apresenta em cena como uma espécie de filhote assustado de Madonna, Gene Wilder e Elijah Wood.
For all its noise and distractions and CG decal, this Wonderland is a zone void of imagination; it proves how relatively mind-blowing Avatar's Pandora actually was.
A fun film with awesome visual design. I think that over time detractors will mellow and Burton's Alice will become a classic. Bandersnatches and Futterwackens not withstanding.
Could have been called Alice in Blunderland, Burton's latest is inferior to the childish Disney feature in nearly every way.
The Alice books gained fame for being totally unconventional, and you decide to make a totally conventional movie out of them?

The imposition of a fairytale quest structure turns the surrealist wanderings (and wonderings) of a free-associating dreamer into a brusque crash-zoom, as Alice hurtles towards her appointment on the good-versus-evil battlefield.
A bland adventure fantasy, Alice in Wonderland may be pretty to look at, yet offers nothing more than Tim Burton's now generic and uninspired brand of filmmaking.
Even though Burton is unable to channel much suspense or awe, the film is a sumptuous visual delight. It all adds up to a mildly enjoyable adventure, sadly lacking in ambition.
An endless series of tedious set pieces, flat characterization, lethargic visual effects, a waste of raw talent...
Despite stunning visuals and fine performances Alice in Wonderland never really goes anywhere. Or rather it goes somewhere we've all been before.
More Disney than Tim Burton.
...an endeavor that's big on spectacle yet small on plot...
Burton's imagination never lets up ... and while those 3-D effects do seem to fade into the background, you can feed your head on his Wonderland for the entire trip.
For all of the wild, 3D effects, eccentric characters and sly nods to its source material, the highlights ... are the performances of his two favorite actors--Johnny Depp and Helena Bonham Carter.
Wobbles along as average entertainment garnered from a great book.
That Johnny Depp's take on the Mad Hatter is comparatively one of the more subdued performances tells you just how out there Tim Burton's film is.
It's the kind of movie that should inspire you to get a Blu-ray player and hi-def television if you don't have them already.

Storytelling has never been Burton's strong suit and his weakness is here compounded by a desire to somehow squeeze Carroll's topsy-turvy, logical-illogical tales into a teen-friendly, Disney-approved, big-screen adventure.
Time to take some of Lewis Carroll's advice, Tim: eat me.

This latest rendition of "Alice in Wonderland" is a journey worth taking mainly to see Tim Burton's imagination at play. The story is so well-known, but you haven't seen it done quite in this way before.

The movie is seeped in distinctive visuals, lavish photography and set design that recalls the wondrous texture of "Harry Potter." What, then, held them back on taking further creative opportunities with the story?
Though visually stunning, Alice In Wonderland is more funny than anything else (thanks mostly to Depp's Mad Hatter).
The magic of this version of Alice in Wonderland is undoubtedly, in the Burton touch... [Full review in Spanish]
No amount of production design can make up for directorial laziness. This Alice in Wonderland would be better if it were shot in black-and-white on VHS tape with actors in furry mascot costumes.
Alice in Wonderland is one of those tragic movies whose frame story is actually more interesting than the story itself.
It's horribly generic. This is a Disney film and it feels like a Disney film, whereas I'd hoped it would feel like a Tim Burton film.
If Burton and other filmmakers want to empower girls, perhaps, just once, they might show them how characteristics other than physical strength and agility are valuable.
It's seriously beautiful at intervals that command attention. There's a war theme in it that's pursued with surprising gravity.
Despite some intriguing visual aspects, "Alice" proves to be quite dull, unable to overcome an internal battle with the film's overall tone.
This joyless adaptation of a beloved story comes up short in almost every way.
But Depp's performance is richer and more coherent than the film itself-a rather laborious narrative that careens through a string of set pieces without transporting us.
Take your own trip down the rabbit hole and don't be late because you've got a very important date with Disney's ALICE IN WONDERLAND.
Director Tim Burton's effort here is a mild disappointment.
Depp is nothing short of astounding as this mad in the best of ways Mad Hatter.

You might not peg Norman Z. McLeod as a comic absurdist but the former animator dives into the witty nonsense of Carroll's world with the same rapid-paced, straight-faced energy as his two Marx Bros. comedies...
An eerie collection of irritating, semi-paralyzed caricatures screaming at you for 77 minutes.
With apologies to Tim Burton, the version of Alice in Wonderland that I most treasure is Norman McLeod's 1933 film for Paramount.
What the curio lacks is the spirit of the classic novel.

It was hoped that the picture would have a large appeal for children, but the consensus of opinion seems to have been that even the Little Ones had rather see Jean Harlow any day, or else stay home in the nursery and play Tick-Tack-Toe.
Lewis Carroll's ingenious fantasy faithfully screened. A film for all ages and both sexes.
There's a ragtag feel to this Alice in Wonderland, which works in keeping with the absurdity of the situations but fails in making the material stick.
From its eerie Dmitri Tiomkin score to its truly horrific character designs, the 1933 Alice in Wonderland is a fascinating, unintentionally disturbing take on a classic.
A Frankenstein of a movie, an unhappy creature stitched together out of the body parts of other movies.

The worst thing is you can almost bet that an executive at Touchstone has already put the wheels in motion for a sequel to bloat an industry that is already chock-full of uninspiring films such as this one.
Even in this conglomerate era of marketed, predigested mediocrity, this Disney movie slips instantly into the humdrum
For me, 3 Ninjas had its amusing moments but was also tedious at times.
Loud and mindless mini-chop socky stuff.
The film can't seem to make up its mind whether it wants to be a comedy, a fantasy or an adventure film.

Can the trio use their ninja secrets to escape? Will granddad defeat the gun-runner in hand-to-hand combat? If you can't guess the answers to these questions you are under 11 and will absolutely love this film.
Director Jon Turtletaub and editor David Rennie keep things zipping along.
If you are under the age of ten, this movie was made for you.
3 Ninjas isn't a movie, it's a concept for a preview.
A lively, good-looking kiddie action comedy best left to those under 10.
A miserable ripoff of The Karate Kid.
You'll love this movie, if you're a 10-year-old boy. Or 8 years old. Or even 13.
Brazenly exploitative stuff, stirring in anything which has done the business in kids' movies previously, this, of course, should have its target audience laughing like drains.
The movie is saddled with a junky visual style, haphazard editing and occasional out-of-focus shots.
It's just a pity that the three martial arts kids are so charmless.
An entertaining, though hardly original, action comedy for youngsters ages six to twelve.
The fortune earned by Home Alone proved to Hollywood that Americans arc crazy about cute little boys, especially ones who dispatch villains with a sadistic glee bordering on the sociopathic.
For the most part it works well as a movie that is funny, fun, and fairly painless.
Things are in a pretty sad state when Hulk Hogan gives a movie's most touching performance.
movie_title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain

review_content: The franchise is losing altitude fast.
movie_title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain

review_content: Abrasively loud, gratingly acted, appallingly directed and without a moral core, this "3 Ninjas" also boasts a screenplay with the most "Unhhhs" of the decade, that exquisite sound you make when trying to anihilate another human with your foot or a karate
movie_title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain

review_content: Only small children with limited attention spans will be impressed by the lackluster kung-foolishness
movie_title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain

review_content: Filled with martial-arts action, bathroom humor, and slapstick, 3 Ninjas Kick Back even has a politically correct kicker: The champion ninja is a girl.
All movies hope to turn a buck, though few of them actually attain this goal (at least, not in any substantial measure). Then there are movies whose only goal is to turn a buck.
If this first sequel is any indication, however, the 3 Ninjas franchise has already run out of steam.
Who was this movie made for? Not for me, that's sure, but I have a hunch younger kids will find it satisfying.
Even worse than the original ... which was pretty dire to begin with.
Instead of exalting physical grace and virtuosity, this film's slapdash action sequences resort repeatedly to the old trick of accelerating the action to the speed of a silent-film chase.
Worse than the first one. These kids are no Spy Kids.
Clearly made with an eye on the international market, this movie is set for the most part in Japan, shrewdly adding a female ninja to the three boys, thus broadening the potential demographics.
Loud, callow, jejune, infantile, puerile and annoying as hell.
3 Ninjas was a surprising box-office hit with the Saturday matinee family crowd, earning the highest cost-to-profit ratio of that year and instantly mandating this all-too-unnecessary sequel.
3 Ninjas Kick Back is just as lively and engaging as the 1992 original
Fantasy is one thing. 3 Ninjas Kick Back is something else entirely: junk food laced with testosterone.
Immature humor, sexism in trite '90s sequel.
The script is littered with embellishments and underdog clichs.
Earnest but cliche-ridden...you're left with the feeling you've seen it all many times before, and needn't have seen it again.
Though infinitely more real than the symbolically bloated Seabiscuit of over a decade ago, 50 to 1 never completely gets under the skin of horse racing.
The true-life horse-racing tale "50 to 1" takes forever to get galloping - and when it finally does, it's too little too late.
If "50 to 1" were about 15 minutes shorter, all of this might have made for a passable diversion. As it is, "50 to 1," much like Mine That Bird, flags before reaching the finish line.

Wilson has owned and raced horses for years and once had a 190-acre ranch in California. And he has made the kind of film he might have seen as a kid, one where patience and hard work get rewarded at the 11th hour.
Captivating us with the story of the little two-year old horse that could, and did, [Jim] Wilson makes us all feel like winners.
This is a powerful, singular piece of filmmaking.
Demonstrates a willingness to experiment that bodes well for future endeavors.
Ambition should never be chided, but 52 Tuesdays spends most of its runtime trying to shout before it can speak.
Honest, insightful and bravely against the grain, 52 Tuesdays is a magnificent debut for cast and filmmaker alike.
Certainly unique and that carries much creative weight; it also contains dramatic tension, but that is rationed and uneven
I think all the performances in this are terrific except for one and there is one character in this that doesn't work for me at all.

Sensitively directed by Sophie Hyde, this quietly extraordinary film is brave in the best sense...the story side-steps any polemic distractions about prejudice or gender politics to focus on the fraught relationship between child and parent.
A story told in snippets inevitably feels disjointed, despite the best efforts of Hyde and her cinematographer Brian Mason (who also edited the film) to get everything flowing smoothly.

Why does the film fall so flat? Partly it's the fatally tasteful indie aesthetic, evident in everything from Benjamin Speed's ambient score to Bryan Mason's digital cinematography, which aims for ''muted'' and ends up at ''drab''.

It's slow going at times but there's a nice balance to it and in the bravado Billie adopts as she attempts to find a way into the future, there's something both poignant and strangely gallant. Better still, she's "authentic".
The movie stands out for all of the right reasons. It's a breath of fresh air, especially within the Australian industry, and not just because of its unique approach to shooting.
There are very few films out there about trans men (contributing to the misconception that they're rarer than trans women) and 52 Tuesdays handles this part of its subject matter with unusual grace.
The film represents queer characters as fully human - selfish, virtuous, mundane; suffering the micro-aggressions of heteronormativity.
The sensitively observed drama is distinguished by its structurally adventurous approach and the intimacy of its storytelling.
Grippingly plotted and exquisitely thoughtful, 52 Tuesdays is a poignant reminder that neither confusion nor crisis is doomed to be calamitous.
Sophie Hyde barely elaborates on the toll James's transition takes on him and only superficially as it affects Billie's psyche.
A frustratingly fragmented yet warmly intimate portrait of an evolving bond that frays but doesn't sever.
One of the more remarkable depictions to date of a transgender person's journey. Sensitively written and naturalistically performed.
Del Herbert-Jane ... makes this none-too-inspired, if rare, study of transition come authentically to life in his/her every scene.
Add it all up and you get an unconventional coming-of-age flick that creeps up on you, winning you over while slipping in all kinds of commentary on transgender life on the sly.
Brings deft emotional nuance to the seemingly inexhaustibly complex relationship between individual identity and family ties.
Sophie Hyde's debut narrative feature is an unusual take on the 'issue film', which impresses by favouring intimacy, whimsical humour and spiky, inconsistent emotions over preaching.
A flawed yet fascinating Aussie indie.
Formally playful and thematically complex.
One can't but fail to be impressed with the film's commitment to investigate its issues with subtlety and frankness.
Compassionate Australian drama about a teenaged girl's sexual awakening that is complicated by her mother's transgender transition to manhood. A smart, adventurous film...
What seems to be a queer issue film morphs into a rich thematic brew depicting how family, sexuality and time are all bound up in defining one another.
There's a candid urgency to it, and an engaging, mercurial lead from Tilda Cobham-Hervey as Billie.
There are interesting moments throughout and the performances of the non-professional cast, particularly Cobham-Hervey, are very good.
Rough around the edges but sophisticated where it counts.
It's an imperfect but remarkable little film, and it gives us the chance to see, in Cobham-Hervey, the birth of a star.
[Fifty-Two Tuesdays] is the rare Australian film that actually has something to say.
The desire to look - at others and at oneself - is taken for granted as a natural and healthy one in 52 Tuesdays.
Hyde and her screenwriter Matthew Cormack tackle all this with persuasive confidence, conveying subtly, and with periodic comedy,
52 Tuesdays brought honesty to the screen.
This is precisely the kind of filmmaking that should be encouraged and while 52 Tuesdays is not entirely successful, it is compelling and exciting debut on several counts.

Well-drawn and well-acted, this microbudget Australian pic deserves to be seen by everyone. Genuine and realistic, this is empathetic without kowtowing to overwrought trans tragedy: Adelaide Buyers Club this ain't.
Sophie Hyde's breathtaking feature debut 52 Tuesdays explores the boundaries of both cinema and gender identity in a seamless way.
Live this up, a wholesome family film this delightful doesn't come by very often.

Funny wish-granting story has some mild scariness.
While sitting in thrall of it, it's only natural for the abused mind to scramble to find reason in an otherwise meaningless entertainment.
Worthy messages, but snarling, scary dogs in animated film.
The great majority of the film's inappropriately slow-moving 76 minutes are taken up with basically nothing at all.
A Cat in Paris is easy enough on the eyes yet never quite justifies feature-length status.
A charming little French animation (not suitable for very young children,) directed by Alain Gagnol and Jean-Loup Felicioli...
Here's an adult animation from Belgium with a sly, geometrical animation style and a story that combines the French policier with the American gangsters that originally inspired them.
A Cat in Paris is animation, yes, but the story, its many threads and mature theme is aimed squarely at the adult and older teen audience that can appreciate a stirring drama in anime form.

Jean-Loup Felicioni and Alain Gagnol draw inspiration from Expressionist painters to give their short but not-too-sweet animation its distinctive fluid style...its light and shade perfectly matching the night-time skyline where much of the action is set.
...will delight adults as well as the children who are its target audience,
It's so wonderfully fun that I'm now hoping it wins the award come Oscar night.
This unexpected Best Animated Feature Oscar nominee is sleek, stylish animated escapade that makes vivid, affecting use of its brief running time.
A Cat in Paris, France's recent Oscar-nominated animated feature, suffuses its story of gangsters and thieves with a playfulness as nimble as the feline after which it's named.
A slight story but delicately drawn with a feline, jazzy score.
A charming, visually sparkling Parisian fantasy with a dark edge.
It's difficult to imagine the audience for this pretty but hollow film.

The human faces are similarly modern-artish, though more Modigliani, and there's a very funny yapping terrier who yaps on regardless even when winter weather reduces him to two paws sticking up through thick snow.
Some of the violence may be a little much for younger viewers but the unconventional story + carefully considered characters make this a must.
A Cat in Paris does feel a little lightweight - and, at 70 minutes, a little short - to venture unaccompanied into commercial cinemas. Still, a pleasant little trifle.
[W]hy does this children's book of a film morph, after a delightful, beautifully observed, feline-biographical opening, into a gangster crime story? It's weird, is what it is.
A slight, attractive tale: a childlike fable of a little girl and her preternaturally intelligent cat that swiftly devolves into a very old-school cops and robbers yarn.

Elegantly hand-drawn in a style that is part Picasso-esque faux naivete, part noirish chiaroscuro, A Cat In Paris [has] enough action, intrigue, suspense, comedy and romance to fill a film far longer and less lean than this.
It's dead cute and exceedingly French, with all the somewhat arbitrary plotting that implies.
Charming. We'll be watching for what Feliciol and Gagnol deliver next.

Beautifully animated and gorgeously designed, this is a hugely enjoyable and deservedly Oscar nominated French adventure with an emotionally engaging central story, delightful characters and a terrific score.
Serge Besset's jazzy score and some smart dialogue help things along, and the finale atop Notre Dame is quite something.
A pleasantly flickering hand-made comedy-thriller in which Dino, a cat belonging to Zo, daughter of a widowed female police superintendent, gets involved in crime.
The old-fashioned 2D animation is a welcome change from the current 3D obsession. Charming.
An animated film with the cozy charm of an advertisement for Starbucks French Roast, A Cat in Paris is all design and no danger.
Unoriginal and mired in bad jokes.
There are wild chases and fever dreams, and sometimes the thieving and the thieves become a muddle. But the animation of A Cat in Paris itself is so artful, it steals the day.

A nifty little caper in which blustery gangsters, intrepid detectives, cat burglars (one of them literally feline) and a little girl named Zo scamper across nighttime rooftops unraveling a pleasantly tangled plot.
There's hardly a frame wasted here.
Doesn't enchant.
Very atmospheric animated policier should deliver the goods for older as well as younger audiences.
The visuals of A Cat in Paris resonate in any language, and it doesn't hurt that the picture features a stunning, stealthy Bernard Hermann-style orchestral score by Serge Bessett.
A barely feature-length diversion that lacks the energy to grip younger viewers or the depth to impress adults, but it earns respect with its makers' dedication to old-school craft.

ections of A Cat in Paris feel draggy even at the abbreviated running time of 65 minutes. But in the best parts, the crisscrossing plot strands all pause for a moment, and we just get to watch and listen to what's going on in this stylishly imagined world.
A very under-developed French animated thriller that fails to engage our emotions.
Seems slight and unremarkable...
Where do cats go at night? Animated Cat delightfully answers that eternal question for young and older audiences [in] a city of shadows enveloped in noir sounds of jazz.
Its imaginative artistry - and brevity - keep you from dwelling on the shortcomings of its story-telling.
It's a sweet and disquieting excursion made by filmmakers whose eyes and ears and imaginations are in marvelous sync.
A Cat in Paris is an animated delight, a hand-drawn puff pastry.
"A Cat in Paris" has a low-key charm and pleasurably laconic visual style.
Although "A Cat in Paris" is new and was nominated for this year's animation Oscar, it already has the feel of a movie that will stand the test of time.
A Cat in Paris falters in the middle with too much farcical plot involving a clumsy, murderous gang, but it finds itself with a neat climax amidst the gargoyles atop the Notre Dame cathedral.
Directors Jean-Loup Felicioli and Alain Gagnol favor a modish visual style and a jazzy score, both of which are charming.
If you're an animation buff or a lover of Paris, you won't be disappointed.
At a little over an hour, it's a slight but visually charming adventure.
Like a cat nap, it gives us a brief, refreshing dream with little to remember.
"A Cat in Paris" has a jazzy, relaxed beauty; it's old-school, hand-drawn animation, and you sense the fun the artists were having.
Imagine Disney's The Rescuers had it been directed by Alfred Hitchcock, and you're zeroing in on the tone of this Oscar-nominated charmer.
Animated thriller's action makes it best for older kids.
An animated delight, and certainly not just for kids.
While the fluid hand-drawn animation provides a pleasant stylistic alternative to the predominance of 3D computer animation in the marketplace, the story leaves a lot to be desired.
[It] glories in striking silhouettes, a slinky '50s beat, a bright storybook palette and an entrancing brand of make-believe that grown-ups can believe in.
Twentysomething caped-crusader fans may get a warmer buzz of nostalgia here than they will at The Dark Knight Rises.
Come for the film, stay for the urban-mural visuals, leave vaguely satisfied.
A Cat in Paris is thrilling, and a thrilling example of traditional ink and paint cartooning.
It's a fun and exciting film that both kids and adults can enjoy.
This French import is a welcome (read: hand-drawn as opposed to CGI) movie that packs a lot of punch in its hour-long running time.

In this chase film, children's love of pursuit, of running and jumping and hiding and seeking, transforms the City of Lights into a playground where even a mother bounds along car roofs to reach her daughter. The story, though, lags behind the animation.
...has a delightfully idiosyncratic animated aesthetic - it's like an intermingling of Art Deco and Cubism - but the story is all odd angles
The film's stylized visuals combine simplistic, geometric figures with more elaborate and distinctive backgrounds that effectively provide a sense of place.
The animation and style is wonderful, the voice acting is great, the story is fantastic and you absolutely won't regret checking this film out.
This is some dark stuff for a children's movie. But the story is told with charming, hand-drawn animation, making it much less frightening than it would be in live action.
This film is gorgeous.

Although it offers a dungeon, a curse and a shocking theft, this flat, anodyne movie is unlikely to join the pantheon of holiday classics, so keep a rein on your expectations and accept that you'll need something more to salvage the evening.

review_content: This is hardly one for the cynics. It's a big, wet, sloppy lick of a film that's going to jerk your tears, and then some.
It quietly boosts a message of resilience and self-belief to young girl audiences, advising them that it's always a smarter move to love nice boys and dogs rather than abusive jerks and pet haters.
There is apparently a sizable overlap between people who like films in which cute dogs scamper around happily, and people who like films in which cute dogs drop dead every half an hour.
Friendship wears a furry face in this family fable full of love and loyalty which will have dog lovers wagging their tails.
As it makes its pitch to become the modern-day Lassie, it has old-fashioned charm to spare.
The subject matter is perhaps a tad grown-up for the smallest children, but there's enough heart and canine soul here for genuine cross-generational appeal.
Is A Dog's Journey manipulative? Absolutely. Is it effective? Hell, yes.
Like the first film, it is based on a book by W. Bruce Cameron, and follows the same saccharine premise, that a much-loved family dog keeps being reborn as other dogs.
Only its restlessness feels novel, tailored as it is to wet-nosed viewers made distractible by hours of scrolling through floof-centric Instagram feeds.
It's preposterous, not half as much fun as last time and, crucially, not at all sad.
A steady stream of corn-syrup sentiment binding what would otherwise amount to a feature-length montage of adorable doggy reaction GIFs.
I literally had tears going down my face about three times, even as my rational brain was saying, "don't you dare get sucked in by this!"
Josh Gad's canine voiceover is as testing as the near two-hour running time.
Gail Susan Mancuso's film brings younger viewers into some admirably weighty themes, using winning doggies, light interludes and a broad scope to impart its wisdom.
Pure rerun of A Dog's Purpose: Pooch Bailey returns again and again (again) in different bodies to love and serve his humans. A sappy tail, pleasantly daydreamy. I'm not crying you're crying.
A tired melodrama, playing like a Tyler Perry movie, but with dogs.

Director Gail Mancuso, a TV comedy veteran, gets the desired effect-as manipulative as it may be-out of both the funny scenes and the sad ones, leading up to a finale that can only be described as weapons-grade tearjerker material.
Even the crustiest viewers (count me among them) must credit director Gail Mancuso for a handful of sequences that, amid all the glop, are capable of softening a hard heart.

Through no fault of Kathryn Prescott, the larger portion showing CJ as a teenager up to her young adult years simply doesn't work, mainly because the writing becomes so episodic and fast-moving that it's hard to care about anything
A Dog's Journey is hackneyed, saccharin, weepy, cliched, predictable and formulaic. And it's a must-see for any dog lover.
A Dog's Journey is every bit as sentimental as its predecessor.
Sticking to one long story is a problem for A Dog's Journey. You could say the sequel bit off more than it could chew! Eh? Eh?
Like opening up a Hallmark card and getting sprayed in the eyes with napalm.
I enjoyed the film, as many will, in a split-brain way that goes to the essence of fantasy -- half-believing what I wanted to be true, embracing the emotional manipulation whenever possible.
The sequel to 2017's A Dog's Purpose is equally saccharine and emotionally manipulative and yet somehow less interesting... which is saying something.
Fortunately, this fantasy about a dog's constant reincarnation is better than Cameron and Minchon's disappointing 'A Dog's Way Home' earlier this year.
Just as in the last movie, multiple dogs die in assorted and depressing ways here. Since we already know the game of this story, it's much easier to become numb to it...
A Dog's Journey ends in bittersweet fashion, but with the suspicion that this franchise will live on.
It's less egregiously tonally divided than A Dog's Purpose, but still the same weird mix of tearjerking dog death, soapy drama, and kid-friendly comedy.
Doesn't everyone believe that all dogs go to heaven?
Director Gail Mancuso has infused this movie with heart and sensibility, and it revolves around the turns by Prescott and Lau.
Resistance is futile. Scratch its belly.
The love we share with our canine companions is one of the simplest emotions there is, and to build an entire film around manipulating that love is lazy storytelling.
Are the pups on screen cute? They sure are. Is that enough to make this movie worth seeing? Absolutely not.
A corny but effective tearjerker for kids and families.
I suppose it's a genuine achievement that a movie packed with as much delightful canine (and agreeable human) talent as this one should be so insufferable.

Warm and fuzzy but a bit lacking in substantial bow-wow-wow, this franchise nonetheless feels like it's turning into a faithful movie companion that's figured out its own secret to coming back again and again.
Do not underestimate just how thin it wears, hearing a medium-grade soap opera plot filtered through a dog's mentality -- but it works, all right? It's shameless, but it works.
Watery eyes definitely become the order of the day a few times in the calculating little family film designed to work the ways it does as a sequel to 2017's 'A Dog's Purpose.'
If you like watching dog videos -- and who doesn't -- then the film is right up your alley. It's destined to put a smile on your face.
The script is bluntly by-the-numbers when it comes to plot points, many of which you can safely predict...
...unlike Marley & Me, this one's a bit predictable and thus falls short of tugging at your heart strings.
Not the most compelling tale, not compellingly told.
Man's best friend deserves something better. [Full review in Spanish]

A Dog's Journey takes a little time to explore ways that dogs can help people in ways we are only now beginning to understand. Learning how they can literally sniff out tumors is frankly more interesting than a plot recycled from a soap opera.

This is the type of movie where all characters are either "good" or "bad," nothing in between, and the only emotions are "happy" and "sad." It's as if it was written from the emotional mindset of a dog.
A screenplay full of cliches and platitudes muttered by characters made out of wood, including the canines.
There are plenty of "awwww" moments to go around, with reconciliation, support, and reunion, and plenty of human and canine characters to care for.

It's about halfway through the film when one realizes how much deeper Mancuso and team are going with this dog's journey... It's about how dogs can fill the hole in your heart that a person might leave.
Is A Dog's Journey one of the sweetest canine films out there, or one of the meanest?
An emotional and heartfelt sequel with real purpose makes this a journey well worth taking.
A scattershot story line, covering many years and leaving plot holes and unanswered questions. Coincidences abound to the point of ridiculousness.
The screenplay consists of some terribly clichéd dialogue...
Bailey remains annoyingly dim and hyperactive, and Gad's voice performance is still cutesy and cloying.
Has its sweet, genuine moments and great performances to carry the story, but the overall blandness of the manipulative story makes this sequel an [insert dog pun here].
Television Director, Gail Mancuso, directs an underwhelming feature film that feels like separate TV episodes that lack depth, resulting in a tedious dull drama.
It's pretty rare that a sequel improves on an original, but that is certainly the case with Gail Mancuso's A Dog's Journey.
We are facing a film of emotional crassness. [Full Review in Spanish]
[A] strange mixture of juvenile humor, mawkish melodrama and insufferable cuteness...this dog has had its day, and then some.

These lessons give the film its purpose - to show kids the importance of good role models. It's a safe notion, in a relatively safe feature, but it's one that should have parents pleased and their kids inspired.
Shamelessly sentimental, this sequel again chronicles canine reincarnation.
I wondered, if you could just recut this movie and take out the narration...
The characters were written so serious...but it's a good rental, and I did enjoy it.
Sequel is as sentimental and emotional as the first film.
Lachrymose...insipid.
A Dog's Journey exists solely to allow moviegoers to feel feelings about dogs for 108 minutes. It is saccharine and unrelentingly sentimental, gleefully pushing emotional buttons.
It makes Old Yeller look like a laugh-fest.
A stale melodrama that doesn't exhibit much bite, much bark, or, really, much of anything.
Warmhearted story about a reincarnated dog through several lives. And let's hear it for the dog actors, these guys are award worthy.

I think it works better than the original due to following one character over the years rather than many, thus making it feel more cohesive rather than disjointed. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Tense Family Material, etc. - Available)
A Dog's Journey is a series of moments, tenuously connected with little impact or consequence, with Josh Gad narrating the whole thing in an increasingly irritating juvenile tone.
'A Dog's Journey' has more bite than you might think.
Sure it's a whole lot of fluff, but you just can't help but go along and pet this story as it strolls along.
The film is aimed at those who turn their long-suffering pets into emotional prosthetics, characterized by unconditional surrender to their masters. [Full review in Spanish]
It is the sequel to the 2017 film A Dog's Purpose, but the new film stands on its own.
There is so much obvious emotional manipulation occurring in 'A Dog's Journey,' you may as well be handed a box of tissues and a fluffy pillow when you enter the cinema.
It's all sweet, silly and kind of spooky as it was the first time around.
Much of this drama is entertaining and, at times, compelling, even if it won't take a Pekingese long to work out where the plot is going.
If there are to be more sequels, I'm hoping that future Baileys cut the chat and hark back to a time when heroism trumped cuteness and movie dogs left the punchlines to the human members of the cast.

I went into it feeling a bit low and came out of it feeling a bit better. It's a reminder that sometimes there's a beauty in just going along with ordinary life, which is short, even more so for dogs.
This shaggy dog sequel scratches all the designated spots.
What if dogs really aren't this annoying when we get to hear inside their head? What if they're actually very smart or lovely?
Even with a relatively merciful runtime of a hundred minutes, A Dog's Journey still manages to wear out its welcome before the credits roll.
A truly high-quality production that smartly pays attention to pacing, performances, cinematography, score, messages and...[it] authentically pays off.

While the supernatural element makes for the film's most entertaining sequences... the story distinguishes itself from other anime offerings through its attention to both visual and emotional realism.
Although the film may lack the charm found in similar offerings, it pulls genuine emotional punches that only enhance its sense of wonder.
Its many warm and charming moments, which sometimes recall the work of Studio Ghibli, should earn the film a solid fan base in America.
It offers a realistic portrayal of Momo's emotional state, but this comes at the expense of a deeper exploration into both the story's lush supernatural landscape and its inhabitants.
As Momo conquers her fears, averts a tragedy and finally sees the beauty of her surroundings, the movie grabs your heart with the softest of hands.
A comic adventure that suffers from a dearth of both laughs and thrills.
The tone is generally light, the bickering goblins make a boffo comedy team, and while there's a recurring fart joke, it borders on classy. That's the power of good anime.
Literally beset by goblins, this strained animated effort should have concentrated on the human elements of its story rather than the supernatural.
A beautifully connected film on a spiritual level. Overall, Okiura stays very focused on Momo's emotional journey, which is smart.
Thankfully, the supernatural elements never overshadow the human story occurring in the foreground.
The stunning animation, from the energy of its characters' faces and bodies to those entrancing backgrounds securely rank the film alongside other worthy entries in post-Miyazaki anime.
Who cares if there's a better film to be cut out of A Letter to Momo's frames? If the experience of watching is exhausting, it's no less rewarding.
A sweet tale of a sad girl who moves to a new place and meets supernatural pals.
A striking example of Japanese hand-drawn animation, it casually combines things you wouldn't expect in one place.
Had Okiura cut some of the supernatural shtick he would have had a far more affecting and mercifully shorter movie.
After the fashion of Miyazaki's films, the visual style achieves a satisfying balance between realistic detail and painterly flourishes, and the laid-back pacing allows one to savor both.
"A Letter to Momo" is unquestionably lovely to look at, but viewers may not be able to shake the feeling that they've seen much of it before, and done better.
Scene after gorgeously hand-drawn scene offer a visual feast, but two hours of it is a bit too long.
Remains absolutely lovely with intimate moments and heartbreaking with honest communication, sold with gorgeous animation that brings out character detail and fantasy peculiarity with equal grace.
It's difficult to imagine any children's movie retaining the attention of its intended audience for two hours, but this movie feels especially monotonous.

Despite the hand-drawn film's supernatural edge, one of Okiura's lyrical strengths is acquainting a viewer with the poetry of the real - animated reflections of ordinary, beautiful things we see in everyday life without actually noticing them at all.
It's (... ) remarkable since it's a tender, sweet film that softly explores the resolution of loss on levels that parents and children both will understand, enjoy and savor.
The new anime A Letter to Momo feels like the movie that Hayao Miyazaki's final film should have been.
Filmmakers of live-action fare, even that which ostensibly is aimed at adults, could learn a lot from its tact.

A Letter to Momo is a sweet, melancholy story with beautiful artwork that pays special attention to both natural surroundings and traditional Japanese animistic spirits, but its appeal is overwhelmingly human.
A sweet, heartfelt, yet never maudlin story about an 11-year-old girl's coming to terms with the loss of her father.
Though made by the studio Production I.G, this is a markedly Ghibli-esque affair, overtly referencing Miyazaki's My Neighbour Totoro and Princess Mononoke among others.
The hit-and-miss English dub flattens some of the dramatic beats, but this is still a rather lovely piece of work.
This accessible and heartfelt anime charms because of its honesty and impressive attention [to] detail.

Here, magic-realism and emotional realism run together. The story can lapse into jokiness or drag its heels a little. But when Momo's anguish bursts, and she soon realizes how sad her mother's truly been, the film bursts to life.
Yet the stunning artwork and detailed description of daily life on the Japanese islands sure makes this one worthy of a few visits. Highly recommended!
A cathartic, brilliantly conceived and executed blend of fantasy and drama.
Filmmaker J.A. Bayona goes three for three with A Monster Calls, a movie more steeped in fantasy and fairy tale than his previous one.
There's a truly monstrous film lurking in here somewhere, but Bayona seems hell-bent on keeping it at bay.
Deeply emotive and heart-achingly sad, A Monster Calls is a tremendous triumph.
There's enough nuance to hold intrigue and enough compassion to be a resounding success.
A Monster Calls gets off to a rocky start, but once Neeson's talking tree starts spouting tales of wisdom, everything tightens as the tears start flowing.
It's a little on the nose, but the film is realized with such sincerity, such vivid imagery, and such raw emotion that it's hard to fault. Just remember to bring Kleenex. Lots of it.
A sensitive and beautifully made lesson in the limits and power of storytelling.
A deeply moving fable about loss and love.
A splendidly rendered, yet oddly ill-conceived terminal-illness melodrama that feels much too dark and serious for audiences Conor's age, and an even more curious fit for grown-ups.
Giving this film to a person who has yet to experience tragedy for themselves is arming them against future strife. I don't just recommend J.A. Bayona's movie, I deem it necessary.
It's all of course nakedly manipulative, much like Bayona's last film, The Impossible. Luckily, his actors sell the hell out of the premise.
A film that is likely to have you in tears the entire way through.

J.A. Bayona has created an unforgettable, emotional experience with A Monster Calls, one that lets us grapple with our most basic human fears and worries, while lighting a beacon of hope that can shine through that darkness.

Bayona ... deluges his story - albeit well acted and technically-flawless - with emotionally coded representational imagery and hectors the viewer with stylistic shifts, mood swings, and frantic pacing.
If you can't connect to the story -- as I couldn't -- A Monster Calls just feels awfully manipulative and hollow.
A movie filled with good intentions but the excessive drama makes the interesting premise feel weak. [Full review in Spanish]
All in all, A Monster Calls is a highly satisfying film.
For those kids who lock into its frequency, A Monster Calls could be a film that changes their lives. For the rest of us, it's a very admirable failure.
It's a beautiful little storm cloud of a movie, that communicates the nuances of grief movingly, but also perfectly illustrates why we sometimes avoid grieving people.
By the end, A Monster Calls certainly provokes some tears, but they're coaxed out by a manipulative hand.
A handsomely mounted (if slightly airless) story of monsters and nightmares, and the real-life terrors that inspire them.
This movie probably actually counts as therapy. The tears feel earned though, rather than cheaply stolen.
A Monster Calls is a coming-of-age tearjerker wrapped inside a web of fantasy and magic.
A film so perfectly aggressive and voracious that seduces. [Full review in Spanish]
My opinion about this film might be conditioned because I didn't understand the argot used in it. Or maybe, there wasn't anything interesting about it. [Full review in Spanish]
The staging and the formal beauty of the film is trapped in a literal interpretation of psychological realism that is maddening. [Full review in Spanish]
It begs you to forgive any flaws ... for the sake of its important message. Under all its flashy visuals, it reminds us that life isn't a fairy tale.
A film where its director stands out as a prodigy on a technical and dramatic level. [Full review in Spanish]

With A Monster Calls, however, J.A. Bayona displays the knowledge, assurance, and wit of a filmmaker truly coming into his own. Entertaining, tonally impeccable, and heartbreaking, this is a monster movie with a very human heart.
A story of a bullied child, a mother with cancer and a bad tempered grandmother. Only the director can save us from this scenario. [Full review in Spanish]

It tries hard to simultaneously be exciting, emotional and magical. And while it doesn't always manage to nail that tricky trifecta, it provides a number of touching moments and a behemoth to remember.
J.A. Bayona's A Monster Calls is a masterpiece. Full stop.
Considering how easily the material could turn maudlin, it's especially notable that Bayona avoids overstatement.
Bayona knows how to turn the screw of sentiment, not so much jerking tears as gradually filling a well of sadness until it can't help but spill out.
A tear jerker for very sensitive people but if you're not one of them, you will not be moved because of the excessive narrative precision. [Full review in Spanish]
A Monster Calls manages to combine fantasy and realism to create a story that deals with grief in a mature, respectable way that is sure to pull at your heartstrings.
Even though it's roaring its message in your face, it's a message that is undeniably important, incredibly moving and honestly delivered.
A glorious, colourful mesh of styles that reflects Connor's inner conflict and turmoil; a melody for his mother's malady.
Darkly inspired, A Monster Calls is highly affecting - but surely too much so as a survival aid for the children who might need it? Yet it's not quite for adult adults either.
Mixing animation and heartfelt storytelling, the film features an impressive break-out performance from Edinburgh actor Lewis MacDougall in the central role.

In my experience, I did not quite feel the painful truth of the characters because I got distracted by the beauty of the images. Despite that, is a very beautiful and exquisite drama. [Full review in Spanish]

Despite its fantastical elements and occasionally obvious plot points, it is a film about emotional truths and an admirable attempt to inject some real heart and soul into a YA adaptation. And not even a love triangle in sight.
J A Bayona has conjured a bittersweet and often painfully moving account of bereavement and growing up.
The technical wizardry exhibited throughout A Monster Calls is complimented by Bayona's assured direction and a tender script by Patrick Ness.
It bravely tackles a difficult subject with grace and sensitivity, and its message is deeply moving and affecting.
The visuals are lush, but Conor's world is small, English and grim. The light at the end of a long, dark tunnel - if it comes at all - will be hard won.
A technically solvent film that has several scenes with an undeniable visual strength. [Full review in Spanish]
"Dark, yes, scary at times, but always part of a beautifully drawn whole."
A visually delightful fantasy film.
A deeply emotional film about loss that will probably have you crying by film's end.
Cinematic childhood without the sugar-coating, a disturbing fairytale without its edges worn off.
A shivery, insightful melodrama, it's truly heartbreaking.
An audacious mix of genres, A Monster Calls brings a dark, fantastical twist to a tale of childhood grief.
Every time the narrative seems to be headed toward some pat, sentimental revelation about loss and healing, it lands just a little off-center, avoiding predictability.
